title: Out of date python in snap?
body:
After installing the certbot snap on Ubuntu 20.04 and running `/snap/certbot/current/bin/python3 --version`, it tells me the bundled python version is 3.8.10. This is several security releases behind the current 3.8.13.

1) Is this using Ubuntu 20.04's patched version of 3.8.10 that includes all the recent security fixes?
2) If not, has someone carefully examined the issues fixed between 3.8.10 and 3.8.13 and determined they don't apply to certbot?

If neither 1) nor 2) is the case, then its necessary to update the bundled python and keep it up to date with security releases. Otherwise, sorry for the false alarm, just checking!

title: Hook to early skip renew ?

labels.name: priority: unplanned
labels.description: Work that we believe should be done, but does not have a higher priority.

body:
Hello Certbot developers,

I think at the moment there is no way to have a renew hook being able to skip renew if some conditions fails.

Here is that I'm trying to do:
Considering a 3 hosts HA cluster with floating IP/DNS address. Each server has its own certificate matching it's DNS and also have one certificate matching DNS name pointing to the floating IP address.
Of course, the only server being able to renew the certificate for the floating address is the one that currently have the address, so I added in the renewal config file a renew_hook calling a script syncing the update certificate and associated to config to peer host.
It's working perfectly fine, and if I try to renew this certificate on non-master server it's failed to verify the challenges and renew fails, renew_hook is not run in that case.

So that's pretty okay except embedded certbot.service run by certbot.timer appears as failed on slave servers, succeeded on master.
The only way I see to avoid this is being able to see something like renew_skip_if hook in renewal config that could run a command to check if the server is being master, otherwise it just skips renewal and keep a success status.

Does it makes sense ? Is this possible at the moment ?

Thanks in advance,

Best regards, Adam.

title: Use f-strings in DNS plugins.
body:
It probably should have been included in #9225 Anyway, everything matching has been replaced with f-strings. Just for the sake of curiosity, I ran a small test with `ipython`, and they're roughly 2-2.5x faster.

```bash
grep -r -E "\.format" certbot-dns*
```

There are still a lot matching this. 
```bash
grep -r -E "\.format" certbot*   
```

I think switching to f-strings is one small step in the right direction of the black/flake8 adoption.

title: nginx plugin UX should infer paths when nginx is built from source

labels.name: priority: significant
labels.description: Issues with higher than average priority that do not need to be in the current milestone.

body:
## My operating system is (include version):
Raspberry Pi OS 9 (Stretch)

## I installed Certbot with (snap, OS package manager, pip, certbot-auto, etc):
Snap

## I ran this command and it produced this output:
`sudo certbot --nginx --nginx-ctl /usr/local/nginx/sbin/nginx --nginx-server-root /usr/local/nginx`
Everything worked normally after I did the awkward workaround for bug #9162

## Certbot's behavior differed from what I expected because:
It's not clear to users they need to specify paths to Nginx's configuration file or binary through flags or how to do so (e.g. run `which nginx` to find the path to their binary and enter it with a flag). Some people (including me, until recently) simply assume that `certbot --nginx` will not work for Nginx when installed from source and opt for manual setup when it actually can.

**⭐️ Opportunities to improve the UX: ⭐️ **
- Instead of failing when Certbot doesn't find the `server_root` or config files where it expects (i.e. only looking where they would be if Nginx was installed via a package manager such as `apt`), it could check the [3 most common places](https://docs.nginx.com/nginx/admin-guide/basic-functionality/managing-configuration-files/#:~:text=(For%20NGINX%20Open%C2%A0Source%20%2C%20the%20location%20depends%20on%20the%20package%20system%20used%20to%20install%20NGINX%20and%20the%20operating%20system.%20It%20is%20typically%20one%20of%20/usr/local/nginx/conf%2C%20/etc/nginx%2C%20or%20/usr/local/etc/nginx.)) instead of failing outright with a generic error.
    - In the (hopefully) rare event Certbot finds multiple inferred paths, it could prompt the user which one they want (e.g. if it sees multiple `nginx` binaries or server roots in say `/etc/` and `/usr/local/`...)
- Could Certbot also attempt to infer where the binary for Nginx is by checking the PATH or relative to where we find the config (e.g. it's *very likely* in `/usr/local/nginx/sbin` or `/etc/local/nginx/sbin`, or `/usr/sbin`)? Sensible default behavior could save people from going [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/36109112/shell-cant-find-nginx).
- As a last resort fail-safe, could the command return helpful hints, such as
    - "We couldn't find your Nginx server root, which includes your config and other server files. Try re-running this command as `sudo certbot --nginx --nginx-server-root /path/goes/here`, changing the path to point to your `server_root`
    -  We couldn't find Nginx installed. Either make sure the `nginx` command is included in your PATH or try re-running this command as `sudo certbot --nginx --nginx-ctl /path/to/nginx`, changing the path to point to Nginx.
    - [A third message that combines parts of the two above...]

## Here is a Certbot log showing the issue (if available):
N/A

## Here is the relevant nginx server block or Apache virtualhost for the domain I am configuring:
N/A applies to whole setup of nginx

title: Nginx plugin doesn't check in a common subdirectory for nginx.conf file

labels.name: priority: significant
labels.description: Issues with higher than average priority that do not need to be in the current milestone.

body:
## My operating system is (include version):
Raspberry Pi OS 9 (Stretch)
Certbot 1.22.0

## I installed Certbot with (snap, OS package manager, pip, certbot-auto, etc):
Snap

## I ran this command and it produced this output:
`sudo certbot --nginx --nginx-ctl /usr/local/nginx/sbin/nginx --nginx-server-root /usr/local/nginx`

> Error while running /usr/local/nginx/sbin/nginx -c /usr/local/nginx/nginx.conf -t.
> 
> nginx: [emerg] open() "/usr/local/nginx/nginx.conf" failed (2: No such file or directory)
> nginx: configuration file /usr/local/nginx/nginx.conf test failed
> 
> The nginx plugin is not working; there may be problems with your existing configuration.
> The error was: MisconfigurationError('Error while running /usr/local/nginx/sbin/nginx -c /usr/local/nginx/nginx.conf -t.\n\nnginx: [emerg] open() "/usr/local/nginx/nginx.conf" failed (2: No such file or directory)\nnginx: configuration file /usr/local/nginx/nginx.conf test failed\n')

## Certbot's behavior differed from what I expected because:
The Certbot tests to see if the `nginx.conf` file is in the `server_root` only, even though it often lives one level deeper in a subdirectory called `conf` (when nginx is built from source). Certbot isn't checking this [common location](https://docs.nginx.com/nginx/admin-guide/basic-functionality/managing-configuration-files/#:~:text=the%20location%20depends%20on%20the%20package%20system%20used%20to%20install%20NGINX%20and%20the%20operating%20system.%20It%20is%20typically%20one%20of%20/usr/local/nginx/conf) and instead only looks in the `server_root` itself.

The problem is potentially here
https://github.com/certbot/certbot/blob/ed7964b424345b5d8ad98335be8f98d5c21059a6/certbot-nginx/certbot_nginx/_internal/configurator.py#L87

My workaround (which is not intuitive or clean) was to create hard links to the `server_root`
> i.e. `ln /usr/local/nginx/conf/nginx.conf /usr/local/nginx/nginx.conf` for the `nginx.conf` file and "include"d files within it, such as `mime.types` as even those were being checked for erroneously in the `server_root` exclusively instead of within the common subdirectory `conf`.


People like me who build nginx from source often struggle how to make `certbot --nginx`. It's not obvious from a UX-perspective that you have to specify with flags the directories of your binaries and configs.


## Here is a Certbot log showing the issue (if available):
```
2022-01-06 19:46:15,782:DEBUG:certbot._internal.plugins.disco:Misconfigured PluginEntryPoint#nginx: Error while running /usr/local/nginx/sbin/nginx -c /usr/local/nginx/nginx.conf -t.

nginx: [emerg] open() "/usr/local/nginx/nginx.conf" failed (2: No such file or directory)
nginx: configuration file /usr/local/nginx/nginx.conf test failed
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/snap/certbot/1669/lib/python3.8/site-packages/certbot_nginx/_internal/configurator.py", line 975, in config_test
    util.run_script([self.conf('ctl'), "-c", self.nginx_conf, "-t"])
  File "/snap/certbot/1669/lib/python3.8/site-packages/certbot/util.py", line 121, in run_script
    raise errors.SubprocessError(msg)
certbot.errors.SubprocessError: Error while running /usr/local/nginx/sbin/nginx -c /usr/local/nginx/nginx.conf -t.

nginx: [emerg] open() "/usr/local/nginx/nginx.conf" failed (2: No such file or directory)
nginx: configuration file /usr/local/nginx/nginx.conf test failed


During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/snap/certbot/1669/lib/python3.8/site-packages/certbot/_internal/plugins/disco.py", line 160, in prepare
    self._initialized.prepare()
  File "/snap/certbot/1669/lib/python3.8/site-packages/certbot_nginx/_internal/configurator.py", line 190, in prepare
    self.config_test()
```

title: Could not reverse map the HTTPS VirtualHost to the original when whitespace in End of File

labels.name: priority: unplanned
labels.description: Work that we believe should be done, but does not have a higher priority.

body:
Certbot throws "Could not reverse map the HTTPS VirtualHost to the original" when trying to parse a vhost file where the last lines after the closing tag are empty (newline) and/or contain a single space in one of those lines. 

This error is really unspecific and i spent lots of time trying to fix it. Also the parser should be able to handle it better. There should be a more specific warning on what file and why its failing.

The Issue and resolving it can be found here https://community.letsencrypt.org/t/could-not-reverse-map-the-https-virtualhost-to-the-original/168559/5 but someone else ran into a similar issue earlier here https://community.letsencrypt.org/t/why-cant-i-certbot-d-toastmastervoice-com-and-create-a-new-virtualhost-and-certificate/131544

This seems to work

```
<VirtualHost *:80>
    ServerName md.thorgerjansen.de
    DocumentRoot /var/www/html/test
</VirtualHost>
```
Something like this seems to fail (not sure anymore where the space was, just removed the tailing lines and it suddenly worked)
```
<VirtualHost *:80>
    ServerName md.thorgerjansen.de
    DocumentRoot /var/www/html/test
</VirtualHost>

 

```

This error is really hard to find and debug and can be really frustrating. Thanks to the people over at community.letsencrypt i solved within 2h what i couldnt solve the day before.

## I installed Certbot with snap:

`snap install --classic certbot`
`ln -s /snap/bin/certbot /usr/bin/certbot`
`certbot`
`Segmentation fault `

## I ran this command and it produced this output:
`certbot`
`Segmentation fault `

## Certbot's behavior differed from what I expected because:
It should not throw a segmentation fault.

## Here is a Certbot log showing the issue (if available):
No log available because the application would not start.

## Here is the relevant nginx server block or Apache virtualhost for the domain I am configuring:
Not relevant

##
Core dump is available, just don't wan't it to put it here in the open.
Got this two times after a fresh new VM. If any more information is required, I would be pleased to provide that.

title: Optionally sign SOA query in dns_rfc2136

labels.name: priority: unplanned
labels.description: Work that we believe should be done, but does not have a higher priority.

body:
I created a pull request: https://github.com/certbot/certbot/pull/9106

I run my own nameserver and have split views for internal and external versions of the same zone.  Since I'm running certbot on the server itself, it finds the *internal* (non authoritative, does recursion) zone I'm trying to do dns_rfc2136 challenges for, and the dns_rfc2136 checks fail.

So I RTFM'd python's DNS library and figured out how to have it sign the SOA query, to make the checks pass.  Now I can generate letsencrypt certs with dns_rfc2136 challenges.

Thanks,
Richard

title: --dns-route53-propagation-seconds not respected?

labels.name: priority: significant
labels.description: Issues with higher than average priority that do not need to be in the current milestone.

body:
We got a report that `--dns-route53-propagation-seconds` is not respected. Quickly looking at the code, this seems like a real problem because that flag is added by the common DNS authenticator class in Certbot and used in the `perform` method which the route53 plugin overrides without calling the parent class.

It looks like the route53 plugin has some additional logic to wait for DNS changes to propagate, but I think we should either respect that flag or deprecate it and remove it from the plugin in the future.

title: Augeas "too many matches" crash when deploying many vhosts to one file

labels.name: priority: significant
labels.description: Issues with higher than average priority that do not need to be in the current milestone.

body:
This was reported on the community forum: https://community.letsencrypt.org/t/certbot-fails-to-install-certificate-augeas-augeasvalueerror/166266

## My operating system is (include version):
Ubuntu 20.04

## I installed Certbot with (snap, OS package manager, pip, certbot-auto, etc):
snap (v1.21.0)

## I ran this command and it produced this output:
    certbot --apache

## Certbot's behavior differed from what I expected because:
Sometimes, Certbot will try to write directives to an Augeas path which matches multiple vhosts.

How this seems to happen is that Certbot starts building up an SSL vhost file from scratch:

1. Initially `/files/etc/apache2/sites-enabled/example.com.conf/IfModule/VirtualHost` is a perfectly good path that matches the vhost we added
2. Then, Certbot adds a second vhost and the `IfModule` now matches multiple vhosts.
3. Then, Certbot adds a third and fourth.
4. Then Certbot tries to modify the first vhost again, but it can't, because the path matches every vhost, rather than just one vhost.

The Apache config file below is enough to reproduce this by running `certbot --apache` and just continuing with all domains selected.

title: OVH-DNS Documentation: Permissions for one domain?

labels.name: priority: unplanned
labels.description: Work that we believe should be done, but does not have a higher priority.

body:
The OVH-DNS documentation instruct to generate an API credentials with the following access rules:

```
  GET /domain/zone/*
  PUT /domain/zone/*
  POST /domain/zone/*
  DELETE /domain/zone/*
```
This will grant access to all zones in the OVH account.

if one wanted to generate certificates for one domain only, say ```example.com``` what are the required access rules?

the following does not work:

```
  GET /domain/zone/example.com
  PUT /domain/zone/example.com
  POST /domain/zone/example.com
  DELETE /domain/zone/example.com
```

I have tried other combinations, such as ending by * and still does not work, the error is not very splicit:

```
Error determining zone identifier for example.com: 403 Client Error: Forbidden for url: https://eu.api.ovh.com/1.0/domain/zone/.
```

any idea which credentials need to be granted for managing certificates for one domain only?

title: certbot not executing python or shell scripts under WSL / WSL 2

labels.name: priority: unplanned
labels.description: Work that we believe should be done, but does not have a higher priority.

body:
If you're having trouble using Certbot and aren't sure you've found a bug or
request for a new feature, please first try asking for help at
https://community.letsencrypt.org/. There is a much larger community there of
people familiar with the project who will be able to more quickly answer your
questions.

done - the relevant posts are [here](https://community.letsencrypt.org/t/certbot-manual-auth-hook-exists-but-is-not-executable/165978) and [here](https://community.letsencrypt.org/t/dns-problem-nxdomain-looking-up-txt-for-acme-challenge-check-that-a-dns-record-exists-for-this-domain/165983) 

## My operating system is (include version):

Windows 10 / WSL 2

## I installed Certbot with (snap, OS package manager, pip, certbot-auto, etc):

`apt-get install
`
## I ran this command and it produced this output:

```
sudo certbot certonly --manual --test-cert --email moritz.luerig@gmail.com --agree-tos --manual-public-ip-logging-ok --preferred-challenges=dns --manual-auth-hook authenticator.py --manual-cleanup-hook cleanup.py -d *.asellus.org -d asellus.org
[sudo] password for mluerig:
Saving debug log to /var/log/letsencrypt/letsencrypt.log
manual-auth-hook command authenticator.py exists, but is not executable.
```

## Certbot's behavior differed from what I expected because:

The file is executable (see this post for details: https://community.letsencrypt.org/t/certbot-manual-auth-hook-exists-but-is-not-executable/165978/5?u=mluerig)

title: certbot --apache fails if vhost configuration filename contains a space

labels.name: priority: unplanned
labels.description: Work that we believe should be done, but does not have a higher priority.

body:
## My operating system is (include version):
Centos 8.3.2011

## I installed Certbot with (snap, OS package manager, pip, certbot-auto, etc):
snap

## I ran this command and it produced this output:
certbot certonly --apache

"Unable to find a virtual host listening on port 80 which is currently needed for Certbot to prove to the CA that you control your domain. Please add a virtual host for port 80."

## Certbot's behavior differed from what I expected because:
Virtual host is running on port 80 as certbot requires.

I renamed the configuration file "/etc/httpd/conf.d/25-host\ non-ssl.conf" to "/etc/httpd/conf.d/25-host-non-ssl.conf" (replacing space with '-') and certbot successfully obtained a certificate.

title: “certbot -q renew” but also output on successful renewal

labels.name: priority: unplanned
labels.description: Work that we believe should be done, but does not have a higher priority.

body:
As discussed here: https://community.letsencrypt.org/t/certbot-q-renew-but-also-output-on-successful-renewal/165629

I would find it valuable, for cron purposes, if there was a flag for `certbot renew` that produces output on renewal failure and output on renewal success, but no output when renewal is not required.

title: Document REQUEST_CA_BUNDLE or add a ca-bundle command for custom ACME providers

labels.name: priority: significant
labels.description: Issues with higher than average priority that do not need to be in the current milestone.

body:
## My operating system is (include version):
All


## I installed Certbot with (snap, OS package manager, pip, certbot-auto, etc):
All


## Certbot's behavior differed from what I expected because:
This is basically reopening #7170 because it is still and issue. The REQUESTS_CA_BUNDLE environment variable is not documents and internal ACME services are becoming more common. The only way I was able to learn about the variable was through the step-ca documentation but this should really be documented by certbot itself. 

Also as stated in that previous bug that a command line switch would be helpful and saving the custom bundle to the certificate conf file so it is automatically used on renewal without having to add the root cert to the system store. It was brought up why add a command switch when the variable works fine. This is a common ability in many applications where you can provide options by either command line or by environment variable because both can be useful depending on the situation.

At the very least this functionality needs to be documented
